column1: A varicocele is the swelling of the veins inside the scrotum.
(This is similar to varicose veins in the legs).
A varicocele in an older man that appears suddenly may be caused by a kidney tumor, which can block blood flow to a vein.

Symptoms include: - Enlarged, twisted veins in the scrotum - Painless testicle lump, scrotal swelling, or bulge in the scrotum - Possible problems with fertility or decreased sperm count Some men do not have symptoms.
- The urologist will make a cut, most often in the lower abdomen, and tie off the abnormal veins.
An alternative to surgery is varicocele embolization.
For this procedure: - A small hollow tube called a catheter (tube) is placed into a vein in your groin or neck area.
